content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple pieces of tissue stained with H&E. There are several large, irregular fragments, likely representing sections of the primary colorectal tumor and associated soft tissue. Additionally, there are approximately 10 smaller, ovoid to round, densely basophilic (purple) structures, which are characteristic of lymph nodes. The task is to systematically evaluate each of these lymph nodes for the presence of metastatic tumor cells.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic examination of all the submitted lymph nodes. This specific tissue piece (the first on the left in the second row) has the typical appearance of a lymph node. The zoom is directed towards the periphery of the node, near the subcapsular sinus. This is a high-yield area to screen, as metastatic cells often first deposit and grow in the subcapsular sinus. The goal is to get a closer look at the cellular population to distinguish normal lymphocytes and reactive cells (like histiocytes) from atypical epithelial cells of a metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic examination of all tissue fragments to identify every lymph node and assess them for metastasis. The highlighted area contains a small, discrete, basophilic structure that, at low power, could represent a small lymph node. It is the first potential lymph node on the left in the middle row, and I need to confirm if it is indeed a lymph node and, if so, whether it contains tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my standard procedure is to examine every lymph node on the slide at high magnification to rule out or confirm metastasis. The green box is highlighting the 7th lymph node from the top (or the smallest node on the bottom left). I am zooming into this specific area as part of my systematic review of all submitted lymph nodes. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The green box is centered on a small, discrete, basophilic nodule located in the upper row of tissue fragments (second from the left). This structure has the classic low-power appearance of a lymph node. In cancer staging, it is imperative to systematically examine every identifiable lymph node for the presence of metastatic tumor cells. Therefore, I am zooming into this area to assess its architecture and cellular detail at high power to determine if it is a positive (metastatic) or negative (reactive) lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to meticulously examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. I would systematically screen each node, paying close attention to the periphery. The zoomed-in area is located at the capsule/edge of one of the lymph nodes in the lower section (the 7th lymph node from the top left). This is a high-yield area because metastatic cells often first arrive and implant in the subcapsular sinus, which is located just beneath the capsule. Therefore, I am zooming here to carefully assess the capsule and subcapsular sinus for any atypical cell clusters. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic examination of all tissue fragments. This particular fragment is located in the middle of the slide, between several larger lymph nodes. It appears to be a small piece of fibrofatty tissue. Within this fatty tissue, there is a small, subtle, and slightly more basophilic (purple) focus that looks suspicious. It is crucial to investigate such areas closely to rule out a small metastatic deposit, lymphovascular invasion, or a completely tumor-replaced lymph node, which might otherwise be missed. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area to examine a specific feature within one of the lymph nodes (the ninth node from the top, counting left to right). The green box is positioned over the hilar region of the node, where blood vessels and lymphatic vessels enter and exit. This is a critical area to inspect, as metastatic cells can sometimes be found in or around hilar vessels. The structure appears to be a blood vessel at low power, and a closer look is necessary to confirm its nature and, more importantly, to carefully search the surrounding tissue and sinuses for any atypical cells indicative of metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the primary task for this case is to stage the colorectal cancer, which requires meticulously examining every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed on one of the lymph nodes in the bottom row (the fourth from the left). I would systematically examine each node at high power. This specific area is chosen for closer inspection to assess the lymphoid architecture and, most importantly, to look for atypical, non-lymphoid cells, particularly in the subcapsular sinus region, which is a common site for early metastatic deposits. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary goal for this slide is to meticulously examine every lymph node to rule in or rule out metastasis. I would systematically review each one. The selected area (indicated by the green box) focuses on one of the lymph nodes (the third one from the right in the bottom row). The zoom is specifically targeted at the periphery of the node, near the capsule and the adjacent fatty tissue. This subcapsular sinus region is the most common initial site for metastatic cancer cells to deposit, making it a high-yield area for screening. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my standard workflow for a cancer resection case involves a systematic, one-by-one examination of all submitted lymph nodes. The green box is placed on one of these potential lymph nodes (specifically, the fourth one from the left in the bottom row). I would zoom into this area to assess its microscopic architecture at high power to determine if it is a benign (reactive) lymph node or if it contains metastatic tumor cells, which are often found in the subcapsular sinus initially. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would examine every piece of tissue on the slide to identify all lymph nodes and assess them for cancer. I have zoomed into this specific area, which is part of the fourth tissue fragment from the top on the right side, because it contains a small, suspicious-looking basophilic aggregate adjacent to a larger lymph node. The aggregate is irregular and fragmented, and its relationship to the surrounding adipose tissue needs to be carefully evaluated. The key question is whether this is just a small, fragmented piece of a benign lymph node, or if it represents a metastatic tumor deposit, possibly with extranodal extension (tumor growing outside the lymph node capsule). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I must systematically examine every lymph node submitted to check for metastasis, which is crucial for staging the cancer. The area indicated by the green box is a small, distinct lymph node located on the bottom row, second from the right. I am zooming in to assess its architecture and cellular composition to determine if it is a positive (containing metastatic cancer) or negative (reactive) lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this specific area, located at the periphery of the seventh lymph node from the top (second from the left in the bottom row), because there is a small, dark, and irregularly shaped focus that appears separate from the main body of the lymph node. This satellite nodule, situated in the perinodal adipose tissue, is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma that has breached the lymph node capsule, a feature known as extranodal extension (ENE). Confirming ENE is clinically significant, and this area requires high-power examination to verify the nature of these cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my standard procedure is to meticulously examine every lymph node submitted for any evidence of metastasis. The green box is located on the lymph node in the bottom row, far right. I would zoom into this area as part of my systematic review of all lymph nodes. This particular node appears slightly fragmented or has an irregular cleft, which prompts a closer look to ensure this is an artifact or a benign feature (like a dilated sinus) and not an area of tumor infiltration. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the parenchyma of a lymph node. The majority of the cells are small, dark lymphocytes, which are normal. However, the sinuses (the lighter pink, less cellular channels) are expanded and filled with numerous larger cells that have abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and benign-appearing, oval to kidney-bean-shaped nuclei. These features are characteristic of sinus histiocytosis, which is a benign reactive change. There are no definite malignant cells, such as atypical glands or solid nests of cells with large, hyperchromatic nuclei, that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node with no evidence of malignancy in this specific field of view.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see fibro-adipose tissue (pink fibrous tissue and white fat cells). The prominent structure in the center is a small peripheral nerve bundle, characterized by its wavy, spindle-shaped cells. There is no lymphoid tissue present, indicating that what appeared to be a small lymph node from a distance is actually just a piece of soft tissue containing a nerve. There is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in this particular tissue fragment.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the architecture of a lymph node being infiltrated by tumor. There are cohesive nests and clusters of large atypical cells with abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and enlarged, irregular nuclei. These malignant cells are expanding the sinuses and are interspersed among the native small lymphocytes, creating a 'moth-eaten' appearance. My impression is that this is a lymph node positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the histology of the lymph node. The normal lymphoid tissue is extensively infiltrated and replaced by irregular nests and clusters of malignant cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, and large, pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei. They appear to be forming poorly-defined glandular structures. This appearance is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a lymph node positive for metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows the interface between the lymph node and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. The lower portion consists of dense, normal-appearing lymphoid tissue. The upper portion is mature adipose tissue (fat cells). At the junction, along the capsule and within the subcapsular sinus, there is a small, subtle cluster of atypical cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more eosinophilic cytoplasm, and irregular nuclei. My impression is that this is a small focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma. This finding would classify this lymph node as positive for metastasis.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows mature adipose tissue (fat cells) and fibrous stroma. Within this tissue, there are clear signs of lymphovascular invasion. I can see several lymphatic channels containing clusters of atypical epithelial cells with hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. There is an associated desmoplastic and inflammatory response. This finding represents a tumor deposit in the pericolic soft tissue, which is a positive finding and is counted as a positive lymph node for staging purposes (pN category).
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see two cross-sections of thick-walled arteries, characterized by their prominent eosinophilic smooth muscle walls and visible internal elastic lamina. These vessels are surrounded by a dense and monotonous population of small, mature lymphocytes, which constitute the normal parenchyma of the lymph node. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, malignant glands, or tumor cell nests in this field. My impression is that this is the hilar region of a lymph node showing normal arteries and benign lymphoid tissue. There is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in this specific view.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes, which constitutes the bulk of the lymph node parenchyma. However, at the bottom of the image, situated just beneath the lymph node capsule within the subcapsular sinus, there are several well-defined clusters and small, abortive glandular structures. These are composed of atypical epithelial cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and enlarged, somewhat irregular nuclei. These cellular clusters are clearly foreign to the normal lymph node architecture. My impression is that these findings represent metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, this is a positive lymph node, indicating that the cancer has spread from the primary tumor.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the edge of a lymph node. The top portion of the image shows fibroadipose tissue. Below this is the lymph node capsule, and then the dense lymphoid parenchyma of the node itself. The lymphoid tissue is composed of a dense sheet of lymphocytes. I do not see any definite nests of atypical epithelial cells or malignant glandular structures within the lymphoid tissue or in the subcapsular sinus. The appearance is most consistent with a reactive lymph node, showing preserved architecture without evidence of metastasis in this specific field of view. A thorough examination of the entire circumference and cut surface of this node, as well as all other nodes, is required to make a final determination.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a section of a lymph node. The tissue is composed of a dense, monotonous population of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. The lymph node capsule is visible, and it is adjacent to mature adipose tissue (fat). I do not see any atypical glandular structures, clusters of large pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli, or extensive necrosis that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field of view is that of a benign, likely reactive, lymph node. There is no evidence of malignancy in this particular area.
This is ROI 11. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see three main components: mature adipose tissue on the left, eosinophilic (pink) fibrous connective tissue at the top, and aggregates of basophilic (purple) cells on the right. These basophilic cells have the cytologic features of lymphocytes. They appear as disorganized clusters and are fragmented. I do not see definitive features of metastatic adenocarcinoma, such as atypical glandular formation, large pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli, or significant desmoplastic stromal reaction. My impression is that this most likely represents a small, fragmented, benign (negative for metastasis) lymph node or a simple lymphoid aggregate in the pericolic fat. To be certain, I would need to examine this area at higher magnification to definitively rule out the presence of isolated tumor cells or micrometastasis.
This is ROI 12 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the periphery of a lymph node adjacent to perinodal adipose and fibrous tissue. The lymph node parenchyma consists of a dense population of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. There is infiltration of these benign lymphocytes into the surrounding fat. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glandular structures, or desmoplasia to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy. The infiltration of lymphocytes into the fat is a benign finding and should not be mistaken for extranodal tumor extension.
This is ROI 13 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the left side shows the edge of the lymph node, which is densely populated with lymphocytes. The right side shows perinodal adipose (fat) tissue. Within this fat, there is a distinct, irregular cluster of dark, atypical cells. These cells are crowded, have large, hyperchromatic nuclei, and are forming poorly-defined nests, which are features of malignant epithelial cells (adenocarcinoma). My impression is that this is a focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma with clear extranodal extension. This finding confirms that the lymph node is positive for metastasis and has an adverse prognostic feature (ENE).
This is ROI 14 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see dense lymphoid parenchyma composed predominantly of small, mature lymphocytes. There is a prominent, acellular, clear space transecting the tissue, which is most likely a processing artifact such as a tear or a fold in the section. I do not see any definitive evidence of metastatic carcinoma. There are no atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or cohesive nests of tumor cells within the lymphoid tissue or the sinuses. My impression is that this portion of the lymph node is benign and reactive, and free of metastasis.
